Award.AwardTitle: The Morphology of Dust-Obscured Starbursts: the e-MERLIN SuperCLASS Legacy Survey
Award.AbstractNarration:
Galaxies -- collections of hundreds of billions of stars all bound by gravity -- are a fundamental building block in the evolution of our Universe. Our own Milky Way galaxy is regarded as 'normal' in the Universe today, stretching 100,000 light years across and forming stars at a rate of 1-2 new suns per year. But, as we look farther out into the Universe, it seems that galaxies in the distant past (10 billion years ago) were dramatically different. Extreme "starbursting" galaxies that produced 100 to 2,000 stars per year were much more typical, and most stars formed at that time came from such starbursts. The awarded team is trying to determine why these galaxies were so important in the Universe's history and why they are so extreme, for example whether or not they are caused by the catastrophic collision of two smaller galaxies, or whether the gas (the fuel needed to power star formation) was more dense and efficient when the Universe was much younger. These extreme starbursts are also heavily obscured by dust, making them hard to see in optical light visible to our eyes. Cutting edge radio-wavelength data from the e-MERLIN telescope will be used to peer through the dust and determine the powering mechanism for the Universe's most extreme starbursting galaxies. This project will support the retention of under-represented students in astrophysics research through participation in the TAURUS program at UT Austin, where undergraduate students spend nine weeks of the summer on a research project. The awardee will be proactive in engaging and supporting under-represented students in communities like TAURUS.

With a unique data set of high-resolution (0."1) deep (4 uJy) radio 1.4 GHz continuum data from e-MERLIN covering 1.77 deg^2 in the SuperCLASS field, the awardees will assess the evolutionary origins of highly-obscured radio galaxies in a statistically large sample (few x 100) out to z~3. The objectives are to answer the following questions: (1) Are the high-SFRs in dusty starbursts primarily driven by galaxy interactions or not? (2) Does feedback from Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) in obscured starbursts play a role in suppressing star-formation? Or is there no discernible difference in star formation seen in starbursts with or without radio-luminous AGN (and what is the dependence on the AGN luminosity)? (3) What do galaxies' star-formation surface densities tell us about the intensity of star formation and relative obscuration geometries (when compared to optical imaging)? (4) Can one learn about the physical origins of the mysterious far-infrared/radio correlation by analyzing galaxies' radio synchrotron slope and radio morphologies? Answering these questions through direct morphological analysis of the e-MERLIN SuperCLASS data products will have significant impact on galaxy evolution studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award focused on a unique dataset in a new patch of sky that is uniquely useful for the measurement of a phenomenon called weak gravitational lensing.  This patch of sky, named the SuperCLASS field, contains five galaxy clusters which are the largest gravitationally-bound objects in the Universe.  Galaxy clusters act like cosmic telescopes, magnifying the light from even more distant galaxies.  The SuperCLASS field has been the focus of a unique survey aimed at measuring the weak gravitational lensing phenomenon at radio wavelengths using the eMERLIN telescope in the UK -- light that has very low energies compared to the light we see with our eyes.  The eMERLIN telescope specializes in returning high-resolution imaging of galaxies at radio wavelengths, which allows us to measure the star-formation rate of galaxies extended in two dimensions on the sky, allowing us to measure galaxy shapes and sizes.

The intellectual merit of this award focused on gathering all of the optical and near-infrared data together in the SuperCLASS field to extract more information about the galaxies in this field, including measurements of their distances, and develop new ways of interpreting the spatial distribution of radio emission in galaxies and link them to the physical drivers of that galaxy's internal physics.  Careful analysis during the course of our award is published in Manning et al. (2020), which gives a catalog of measured light (photometry) over half a million galaxies in the full SuperCLASS field, and goes on to characterize the ~150 galaxies that are detected with high confidence in the eMERLIN radio dataset.  Manning et al. segregate galaxies into those dominated by Active Galactic Nuclei -- or the emission from accretion onto the galaxy's central supermassive black hole -- or instead, galaxies dominated by star formation (as our own Milky Way would be).  In the sample of 150 radio galaxies, we find only 5% are dominated by AGN.  Manning et al. also present an independent reconstruction of the distribution of mass in the SuperCLASS field at a redshift of 0.2, corresponding to the distant where the galaxy clusters lie.  We independently recover the overdense structures.  This work has enabled rich follow-up research of galaxies in the SuperCLASS field to occur, which wouldn't have been possible prior to this award.

The broader impacts portion of this award helped support the Texas Astronomy: Undergraduate Research for Under-represented Students (TAURUS) summer research program at UT Austin.  Two visiting students conducted research under this award in the summers of 2017 and 2018; TAURUS is aimed at the retention of students from under-served backgrounds in STEM careers.  Both students supported under this award have continued on their path in STEM, one graduating and applying to graduate school in physics, and the other just finishing up their degree in physics and astronomy.
